Bucs have Winston; Redskins not sure what they have at QB 
LANDOVER — In Jameis Winston, taken No. 1 overall in this year’s draft, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers figure they’ve found their starting quarterback for this season — and many seasons to come. 
When it comes to the most important position on an NFL team, the Washington Redskins — the Bucs’ hosts today — really have no idea what they’ve got. 
Robert Griffin III, who went No. 2 overall in 2012, was dropped to third string and has been in uniform once all season — and that’s only because the team was dealing with so many injured players who were inactive, it had no choice but to have the unused QB on the game-day roster. 
Kirk Cousins, a fourth-round pick the same year RG3 entered the league, is the starter that coach Jay Gruden chose and is sticking with, despite a terrible ratio of eight interceptions and six touchdown passes so far. 
“Every quarterback that we say is great right now has gone through times when they were inexperienced and they were learning,” Bucs coach Lovie Smith said. “You just have to know that and try to be strong in other areas.” 
The Redskins (2-4) are coming off consecutive losses heading into the game against the Bucs (2-3), who are coming off their bye, and Gruden has labeled this matchup a “code red” for his bunch. 
“We certainly want to get the bad taste out of our mouths from the past two weeks,” said Cousins, who has thrown a pair of interceptions in each of Washington’s four defeats. 
This has been designated the annual “homecoming” game for the Redskins, presumably because the opponent is coming off such a poor season — although a year ago, half of Tampa Bay’s win total came at the expense of Washington, via a 27-7 victory at the Redskins. 
Here are other things to know about today’s game: 
‘Code red’ 
Gruden might have decided to try to create an extra sense of urgency ahead of this game, knowing that his team’s bye week is next, followed by a game at the New England Patriots. The season could be completely out of hand by then. “We are getting backed into a corner right now, and I hope our guys come out swinging,” Gruden said. “I know they will. I know I will.” Defensive tackle Terrance Knighton’s take? “To me, ‘code red’ means: ‘If we lose this, the season’s over.’” 
Key quarters 
Each of these clubs has a quarter that has been problematic. The Bucs have not scored a touchdown in the first quarter, settling for three field goals while being outscored 38-9. The Redskins are getting outscored 46-3 in the third quarter, raising questions about what is happening — or not happening — during halftime. “We’re working on it,” Gruden said. 
Step by step 
Tampa Bay snapped an 11-game home losing streak two weeks ago. A win over Washington would raise the Bucs’ record to at least .500 for just the second time in nearly three years (1-1 earlier this season). They have not had a winning record at any point since November 2012, when they were 6-4 before dropping five in a row. “It’s not necessarily being 3-3 or where we stand in the division, things like that,” cornerback Alterraun Verner said. “I think when you start worrying about those things, you’re over-thinking and adding additional stress.” 
Redskins running game 
Gruden and new GM Scot McCloughan have made a point of saying they want running backs Alfred Morris and Matt Jones to drive their offense. And early in the season, Washington led the NFL in rushing. But it now stands 17th in the league at 107.2 yards per game, averaging only 3.9 per carry. In a loss to the Jets last week, the Redskins were outgained 221-34 on the ground. “It’s a combination of securing blocks, combination of maybe making guys miss, making something out of nothing,” Cousins said. “It could be play calls.” 
Top 5, really? 
The Bucs rank fifth in the NFL in total defense, allowing 322.8 yards per game. They’re fourth against the pass at 202.4. The rankings are deceiving, though, because Tampa Bay has not been good at stopping opponents on third down or in the red zone. As a result, it’s next-to-last in average points allowed at 29.6. Twice, Tampa Bay yielded four TDs in a game. Tags
